Unfortunately, that agreement was not ratified by the Dominion Parliament, ancl consequently, from the stand-point of trade, we occupy precisely the same position towards New Zealand as does the rest of the world. That was not the first at-, tempt which Australian Parliaments had made to conclude a reciprocal Tariff agreement with New Zealand. The first effort of the kind of which I have special knowledge was one which you, sir, made, when, in 1895, you introduced into the South Australian Parliament a reciprocal agreement lietween New Zealand ancl that State. But after the agreement had been tentatively arranged, the New Zealand Parliament altered the items which it covered very considerably by striking out the provision that fresh fruits from South Australia should be admitted free, and by considerably reducing the preference to be granted by that colony to South Australian wines. D . H . DILLON. As" a result .of that alteration . the South Australian Parliament carried an amendment, compelling the Government to lay office aside the agreement. Since that time other Governments-and particularly the Governments of the South African Colonies-hav e done more than we have in concluding reciprocal agreements with New Zealand. An agreement has been concluded between the Dominion of New Zealand and the South African Customs Confederation, which is already having a considerably prejudicial effect upon Australian trade. It is therefore urgently necessary, as honourable members will agree when I supply them with some statistics, that steps should at once be taken to enter into communication with New Zealand, in order to see whether Australia cannot be placed upon at least as good a footing in these respects as South Africa. The agreement between New Zealand and South Africa came into force on the 7th January, 1907 ; that is, a little over two years ago. It is styled an agree-places, ment between the Dominion of New Zealand and the South African Customs Confederation which includes the Cape of Good Hope, Natal, the Orange River Colony, the Transvaal, and Southern Rhodesia. Dried and fresh fruits are admitted duty free, although the ordinary New Zealand duty on fresh fruits is i d . per lb. in some instances, and £d. for the smaller fruits. On wines other than sparkling, the duty is 2s. petgallon; whilst the duty on Australian, wines is ss. per gallon-a . preference of 3s. per gallon in favour of South African wines.
